CARDINAL . The purpose of LAW was to remove petty offences from the sphere of the criminal law . Included in this category were contraventions of LAW . Under section CARDINAL of LAW ( in its former version ) , commission of such contraventions had given rise to liability to a fine ( Geldstrafe ) or imprisonment ( PERSON ) . Section CARDINAL no . CARDINAL of the Act of CARDINAL DATE ( Einführungsgesetz zum Gesetz über ORG ) classified them as " Ordnungswidrigkeiten " and henceforth made them punishable only by fines not considered to be criminal by the legislature ( Geldbussen ) .
The CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act had been foreshadowed in GPE by CARDINAL enactments : the Act of DATE on " regulatory offences " ( Gesetz über ORG ) and , to a certain extent , LAW of DATE ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL of LAW defines a " regulatory offence " ( PERSON ) as an unlawful ( rechtswidrig ) and reprehensible ( vorwerfbar ) act , contravening a legal provision which makes the offender liable to a fine ( GPE ) . The fine can not be less than DM CARDINAL or , as a general rule , more than DM CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . The amount of the fine is fixed in each case by reference to the seriousness of the offence , the degree of misconduct attributable to the offender and , save for minor ( geringfügig ) offences , the offender 's financial circumstances ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

If the act constitutes both a " regulatory " and a criminal offence , only the criminal law is applicable ; however , if no criminal penalty is imposed , the act may be punished as a " regulatory offence " ( section DATE ) .

CARDINAL . ORG are to be dealt with by the administrative authorities ( PERSON ) designated by law , save in so far as LAW confers the power of prosecution of such offences on the public prosecutor and their judgment and sentencing on the courts ( sections DATE and DATE ) . Where an act has come before him as a criminal matter , the public prosecutor may also treat the act as a " regulatory offence " ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The administrative authorities will remit the matter to the public prosecutor if there is reason to suppose that a criminal offence has been committed ; he will refer the matter back to them if he does not take proceedings ( section CARDINAL ) . In the case of a " regulatory offence " having a close connection with a criminal offence in respect of which the public prosecutor has instituted proceedings , the prosecutor may extend the criminal proceedings to cover the " regulatory offence " as long as the administrative authorities have not fixed any fine ( section DATE ) .
The public prosecutor 's decision to treat or not to treat an act as a criminal offence is binding on the administrative authorities ( section DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Subject to the exceptions laid down in the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act , the provisions of the ordinary law governing criminal procedure , and in particular LAW , LAW ( Gerichtsverfassungsgesetz ) and LAW ( Jugendgerichtsgesetz ) , are applicable by analogy ( sinngemäss ) to the procedure in respect of " regulatory offences " ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . The prosecuting authorities ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) have the same rights and duties as the public prosecutor in a criminal matter unless the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act itself states otherwise ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . Nevertheless , various measures permissible in criminal matters may not be ordered in respect of " regulatory offences " , notably arrest , interim police custody ( vorläufige PERSON ) or seizure of mail or telegrams ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . The taking of blood samples and other minor measures , within the meaning of LAW ( a ) LAW , remain possible .

CARDINAL . The prosecution of " regulatory offences " lies within the discretion ( pflichtgemässes ORG ) of the competent authority ; so long as the case is pending before it , the competent authority may terminate the prosecution at any time ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

Once the case has been brought before a court ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , power to decide on a stay of proceedings rests with the court ; any such decision requires the agreement of the public prosecutor and is final ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . As regards the judicial stage ( if any ) of the proceedings ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act attributes jurisdiction in the matter to divisions ( ORG ) of ORG and to chambers ( ORG ; ORG ) of ORG ( PERSON ) and of ORG ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Investigations ( GPE ) into " regulatory offences " are a matter for the police authorities . In this connection , the police authorities enjoy discretionary powers ( pflichtgemässes PERSON ) ; save in so far as the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act provides otherwise , they have the same rights and duties as in the prosecution of criminal offences ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Prior to any decision being taken , the person concerned ( ORG ) has to be given the opportunity of commenting , before the competent authorities , on the allegation made against him ( section CARDINAL ) .

In the case of a minor ( geringfügig ) offence , the administrative authorities may give the person concerned a warning ( PERSON ) and impose on him an admonitory fine ( PERSON ) which , save for any exception laid down under the applicable law , may range from DM CARDINAL to CARDINAL ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . However , sanctions of this kind are possible only if the person concerned consents and pays the fine immediately or within DATE ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . If necessary , the administrative authorities will designate an officially appointed lawyer to act for the person concerned in the proceedings before them ( section CARDINAL ) .
Measures taken by the administrative authorities during the preliminary procedure can in principle be challenged before the courts ( section DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Save in so far as the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act provides otherwise - as in the case of the matter being settled by payment of an admonitory fine - , a " regulatory offence " is punishable by an administrative decision imposing a fine ( PERSON ; section CARDINAL ) .

The person concerned may lodge an objection ( PERSON ) within DATE ( section CARDINAL ) . Unless they withdraw their decision , the administrative authorities will then forward the file to the public prosecutor who will submit it to the competent ORG ( sections CARDINAL sub - section DATE ) and thereupon assume the function of prosecuting authority ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under section DATE , if the ORG finds the objection admissible ( section CARDINAL ) it will , unless the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act states otherwise , examine the objection in accordance with the provisions applicable to an " Einspruch " against a penal order ( PERSON ) : in principle , it will hold a hearing and deliver a judgment ( ORG ) which may impose a heavier sentence ( LAW ) .

However , its ruling may take the form of an order ( PERSON ) if ORG considers that a hearing is not necessary and provided the public prosecutor or the person concerned does not object ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . In that event , it may , inter alia , acquit the person concerned , settle the amount of a fine or terminate the prosecution , but not increase the penalty ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The person concerned has the option of attending hearings but is not bound to do so unless ORG so directs ( section CARDINAL sub - sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) ; he may be represented by a lawyer ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

The public prosecutor 's office may attend the hearing ; if ORG considers the presence of an official from that office to be appropriate , it will inform the latter accordingly ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

ORG will give the administrative authorities the opportunity to set out the matters which , in their view , are of importance for the decision to be given ; they may address ORG at the hearing , if they so wish ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Subject to certain exceptions , section CARDINAL allows an appeal on points of law ( Rechtsbeschwerde ) to be brought against a judgment or an order issued pursuant to section DATE ; save in so far as the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act states otherwise , in determining the appeal the court concerned will follow , by analogy , the provisions of LAW relating to cassation proceedings ( Revision ) .

CARDINAL . The administrative authorities ' classification of an act as a " regulatory offence " is not binding on the court ruling on the objection ( PERSON ) ; however , it can apply the criminal law only if the person concerned has been informed of the change of classification and enabled to prepare his defence ( LAW sub - section CARDINAL ) . Once this condition has been satisfied , either by the court of its own motion or at the public prosecutor 's request , the person concerned acquires the formal status of an accused ( ORG , section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) and the subsequent proceedings fall outside the scope of the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A decision imposing a fine is enforceable once it has become final ( sections CARDINAL and DATE ) . Unless the CARDINAL/CARDINAL Act states otherwise , enforcement of a decision taken by the administrative authorities is governed by LAW or LAW , as the case may be , on enforcement in administrative matters ( Verwaltungs - Vollstreckungsgesetze ) ( section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL ) . When the decision is CARDINAL taken by a court , certain relevant provisions of , inter alia , LAW are applicable ( section CARDINAL ) .
